ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: key topics in the intersection of psychology and AI
I learned a great amount all throughout the semester.

This course makes you a much better / clearer thinker when it comes to the topic of AI. No other course really does this (especially not in the CS department). You learn a whole lot about the history, progress, and debates around AI and how to reason about them via seminar, responses, and a lengthier paper.
I learned a lot about how psychology/cognitive science interacts with AI, the ongoing process/roadblocks in AI, and what expectations/suspicions we shoulld have regarding future applied use of AI!
We learned about the cognitive science of AI and how that informs/is informed by our understanding of the cognitive science of humans/animals.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
It was good to have open discussion.

Weaknesses: Some students naturally had more comments than others, but the professor should make sure not to let them monopolize the conversation. This makes it much harder for other students to find a good time to jump in and participant. Also, students should not be asked to grade each other. It is unethical and puts students in a very awkward position. Finally, it would be helpful if there was some lecture in the beginning to make sure all students are on the same page and provide some foundation.
I think the discussions can be more structured. I felt that sometimes we spent too much time on one topic and ended up not having time for other interesting things to talk about.
Discussion was always lively, enjoyed learning from Julian and other students

Strengths: course structure, discussion, assignments, everything(?)
Weaknesses: only concern is that its a large seminar (~23) which makes it difficult for shy students to speak up. Maybe cap it at 18? Other than that no weaknesses!

the course is a weekly seminar discussion that is often a very free-form and relaxed environment - it's cool to be part of an engaged discussion where the students just interact in their own ways with the material. Julian is a great conversation mediator, and each class often left me recognizing a lot of new ways of thinking about the material

i think the biggest improvement would be making the discussions more accessible to all students, not just the higher level grad students. Maybe start the course by explaining/elaborating more about the readings rather than going straight into further information that many may be unfamiliar with

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Not if you're not a computer science or cognitive science student.
Yes! You do not need any background in Computer Science and will learn a lot.

Certainly. This is a fantastic course. It pushes you to think critically about AI from different angles (psychology/philosophy/practice) while exposing you to a bunch of interesting literature that relates to it. The core assignments are manageable yet fulfilling: 1-1.5 page response every week, then a final paper (basically a much longer response) Honestly of the most engaging seminars out there.  No matter what your major is, you should take this course.

I would recommend this course to another student if they are interested in the realms of AI, cognitive science, psychology, and neural networks! However, I would advise students interested more in the neuroscience side to be careful because some of the readings are definitely more technical/psychological theory based than maybe anticipated. However, this was a wonderful refreshing course where both the students and professor are genuinely interested in the material, which leads for great seminar discussions
Highly recommend, this is one of the best classes I've taken at Yale.
not unless you already had certain knowledge about AI
